If I define a lemma as follows, does the use of Nat. as a prefix to the name risk clashes or confusion with the official Nat lemmas?

Or is the name merely a clue for human readers, and has no significance within lean/mathlib?

import Mathlib.Tactic

lemma Nat.le_or_succ_le (a b: ℕ): a ≤ b ∨ b + 1 ≤ a := by
  rw [Nat.succ_le]
  exact le_or_lt a b

Yes, it risks clashes. But, it's also good practice.

The mathlib naming convention helps protect you from these issues since there's a reasonable chance that if there is a clash at some point, the lemma will (hopefully!) state the same thing.

So a clash is encouraged, because the resulting error/warning will bring our attention to what the lemmas actually say, and check their validity.

I can accept that, if that is indeed what you intended.

Using the mathlib naming conventions also helps you with contributing these things to the library. It saves the step of needing to modify your own project later (assuming you got the name right!)

Sometimes you also need to put declarations into particular namespaces to make use of features. For example, because this is in the Nat namespace, you can write a.le_or_succ_le b if you wish, when a b : Nat. This is the "generalized field notation", a.k.a. "dot notation".
rzeta0 has marked this topic as resolved.
